entry.title: Re: Horizon Theme and Templates for Stories in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hi all,
It appears that these Themes have an issue with line headers when you attempt to use styling rules or even "fill directly the cell".

For example, if you want to style an entire line, you are unable to do so. You can only style the data cells.

The reason is that the saptheme global CSS section "table--styled" has options set that are too restrictive there.

Even with overwriting via page CSS, it is not possible to fix:

.table--styled .sap-custom-table-column-row-headers{ 
background-color: #transparent;
}

The root cause is this line:

.saptheme .sap-custom-table-column-row-headers,
.table--styled .sap-custom-table-column-row-headers{
    background-color: transparent;
    color: #131e29;
}

The temporary solution is to create a dummy CSS class.

entry.title: SAP Customer Checkout Price Update Issue
entry.content:
SAP Customer Checkout is connected with CCO Manager, and all item master data is being synced from CCO Manager.

On certain POS systems, the price for some items is not updating correctly, and the issue appears randomly across items. After checking the SAP Customer Checkout database, I found that the updated price is reflected in the Price Discount entity. However, in cases where the price is not updating, both the old and the new prices are present in the Price Discount entity, and for some reason, CCO is still picking up the old price instead of the new one. Additionally, both entries have the same timestamp.

Since the client is currently live, this is causing significant disruptions in their operations. CCO Version 2.0 FP20 PL03

entry.title: NDC Converter 2.0: Automating Your Journey from BusinessObjects to Cloud Analytics
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) provides a unified platform for data ingestion, semantic modeling, governance and analytics. For teams migrating from SAP BusinessObjects (BO), BDC enables:

  • A governed semantic layer in SAP Datasphere that faithfully reproduces and extends your existing BO universes with standardized naming conventions, hierarchies and calculated measures.
  • Cloud-native analytics in SAC for reporting, planning and predictive scenarios, powered by either live data connections or scheduled replication jobs.
  • A clear modernization path for SAP BW/4HANA artifacts and non-SAP sources, preserving embedded business logic while consolidating disparate models.

By porting Web Intelligence (WebI) content into BDC, you can retire legacy BO infrastructure and establish a sustainable foundation built on remote or replicated tables, graphical and SQL views and published semantic models that are fully consumable in SAC.

 

In this follow-up to our NDC Converter introduction, we‚Äôll showcase its newest capabilities and zoom in on how REST APIs, RPA and the SAP BDC stack work together to fully automate your migration workflow and eliminate uncertainty that is often associated with these sorts of projects.

Analysis & clean-up

Migration kicks off with a thorough source analysis powered by our enhanced scanning engine. After installing a lightweight Windows executable in your environment, NDC Converter uses the BusinessObjects REST API to perform a repository-wide scan - cataloging WebI documents, variables, filters and data sources. Parallel processing enables multiple report structures to be inventoried simultaneously, cutting traditional analysis times from days to hours.

If BO access is restricted, you can export a full content catalog instead and NDC Converter will generate a self-service metadata report for rapid sizing and compliance checks. These automated scans deliver hard metrics on:

  • Volume: total reports, pages, charts and objects
  • Complexity: calculations, variables, dimensions and interactive features
  • Usage: inactive or overlapping content

Armed with this detailed data, we can scope migration efforts accurately within days rather than weeks, giving prospects immediate insight into their BI landscape without manual, time-consuming analysis.

Automated report migration

Once WebI queries are identified, the next step is to align them with target system (usually SAP Datasphere but other options available too ‚Äì for reference see previous blog post). Steps here include:

  • Linking each WebI query to its target system
  • Generating the necessary migration definitions
  • Automatically provisioning and deploying the corresponding tables

If you‚Äôre working with many tables, the ‚Äúmass deploy‚Äù feature lets you push them live in bulk‚Äîno tedious one-by-one clicks.

After tables are deployed, we configure on-demand or scheduled data replication to maintain synchronization between target and source systems, followed by creating graphical and SQL-based views to implement calculation logic. The final step is to publish these views to SAP Analytics Cloud where up-to-date data can be accessed.

The data source layer migration involves analyzing the BO repository, migrating universe metadata and/or transitioning live models based on BEx queries. Upon completion of the initial data migration, a comprehensive semantic model is introduced that mirrors your original WebI structures including dimensions, measures, hierarchies and data. This transformation provides a cloud-ready foundation for all SAP Analytics Cloud initiatives.

NDC Converter 2.0

With your semantic model live, we proceed with WebI reports migration into SAP Analytics Cloud as interactive stories with new high functional coverage. NDC Converter retrieves each report‚Äôs layout, structures, tables, charts, filters and visual elements via the BusinessObjects REST API. A blueprint compatible with RPA processing is produced, covering:

  • Layout & structure: multi‚Äëpage documents, IDs, descriptions, pages/tabs.
  • Tables & crosstabs: calculated and restricted measures, variables and common WebI calculations.
  • Charts: Bar/Column, Line, Numeric Point, Pie, Donut, Heat Map, Tree Map, Bubble, Scatterplot.
  • Formatting & UX: predefined template stories, titles, text, headers/footers, icons.
  • Filters & interactivity: input controls, query filters, single object filters, drill, hyperlinks.

The RPA bot, delivered as a Chrome extension, reads this blueprint and automates the reconstruction of each report in SAC Story 2.0, preserving original tables, crosstabs, charts, parameters and filters. The resulting SAC Stories mirror your WebI reports while leveraging cloud-native data models.

What stays manual (and why)

NDC Converter automates routine migration tasks, allowing your team to focus on strategic design and governance ‚Äì here are cases where automation does not bring added value:

  • Data model (business semantics) design: turning technical structures into robust semantic layer requires continuous alignment on reporting vision.
  • Edge cases & redesign: in situations where 1:1 replication isn‚Äôt optimal, we propose a workaround solution to comply with business and technical needs.
  • Environment setup: Migrating users, roles and platform configurations using a mix of guided best practices and selective automation.

Collaborate end-end delivery

NDC Converter is an ideal tool for complex migration scenarios, automating the transfer of every structural element‚Äîfrom metadata and queries to filters and visual object definitions. Once the converter has recreated the report skeletons in SAC, your BI team can take over the final steps: refining layouts, adjusting chart properties and validating calculation logic. This collaborative workflow ensures that the most time-consuming technical migrations are handled automatically, while you retain full control over presentation, branding and business requirements.

entry.title: Re: Hiding sensitive Price information in Sales Order dis...
entry.content:
Hi @danny_loo 

Thank you for your question.

I recommend exploring KBA 2963264, Role-Based Access to Price Elements, Pricing & Adapting the UI for guidance.

In summary, using Access Restriction for Access to Price Elements is the right approach. However, in public cloud, the restriction framework controls mainly the Price Elements tab. If it was correctly configured, user will no longer be able to open or drill into condition records. However, summary fields like Net Value and Gross Value will remain visible. This cannot be hidden without authorisation objects.

  • For you to fully meet your requirement, you will need to combine two approaches:
  • First you will have to restrict price elements through IAM by setting the Access Price Elements to No Access.
  • Thereafter, you need to hide the net value/gross value through the UI function in the Sales Order app to removed net value field or item list and pricing header. Then publish the variant and assign it to the restricted role.

This way, any user can still open and track orders but they will not see pricing details anywhere.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite Deep Dive and Hands-on Event (Oct 22, 2025 Palo Alto)
entry.content:
Our SAP Integration Suite team is hosting an event at our SAP office's in Palo Alto @ SAP Building 1 on October 22, 2025.  

Whether you are just considering SAP Integration Suite and have a lot of questions, are new to the technology and still getting your feet wet, or are a seasoned user of SAP Integration Suite there is value for you at this event.   We will have SAP Integration Suite product experts leading all sessions at this one-day event.  

We will provide a deep-dive into the capabilities of SAP Integration Suite, take a tour of the latest roadmap, provide an overview of migration tools, services, and the latest financial promotions to make the move, provide a hands-on experience of SAP Integration Suite, and provide time to sit one-on-one with a product expert to get your questions answered.  

During this SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) knowledge-exchange with our product management team, you will:

  • Gain a deeper understanding of SAP Integration Suite with a hands-on learning experience
    • SAP Integration Suite is a modern, scalable, and secure platform as a service (iPaaS), empowering businesses to integrate all applications and systems across SAP and non-SAP landscapes using one solution. It supports real-time data exchange, automation, and API-driven innovation, facilitating business processes across your entire ecosystem, including cloud, on-premise, and hybrid environments
  • Be inspired by a local SAP Integration Suite customer speaker sharing the keys to their success.
  • Dive into advanced use cases and capabilities, including:
    • Cloud Integration to build and run application-to-application (A2A), business-to-business (B2B), and business-to-government (B2G) scenarios with over 3,200 prebuilt integrations
    • Advanced Event Mesh to design, deploy, and manage an event-driven architecture (EDA) that enables real-time business processes at scale
    • Edge Integration Cell to support hybrid integration needs with a cloud or local runtime
    • API-Management to secure, govern, and transform your APIs with management and delivery processes that drive innovation while safeguarding against threats
  • Discover how to leverage the 2025 Transformation Incentive to save money on migration from SAP Process Integration, SAP Process Orchestration, or SAP Cloud Integration on the SAP BTP, Neo environment, and third-party solutions to integrate SAP and non-SAP systems

Register now and bring your laptop! Seats are limited for this hands-on event.

We look forward to seeing you on Wednesday, October 22, 2025, at SAP Building 1, 3410 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA 94304.

If you have any questions about the event please reploy to this post and we'll follow-up with you.

entry.title: Ariba: Rejection approval flow doesn't trigger on IRs
entry.content:
Has anyone implemented a specific approval to trigger if someone in the IR approval flow clicks on Reject?

We've turned Application.Invoicing.RejectRequiresNoMoreApprovals to No and we've tried using InvoiceReconciliation.IsForReject and InvoiceReconciliation.cus_MarkforReject on our approval rules to have a specific approval after rejection. When using the testing tab of the IR Approval Flow, we see the wanted behavour.

But on the actual approvable document, unless something else is first changed in the IR, after clicking on Reject, the approval flow is not resubmitted and regenerated as we need it to. 

Ariba Support suggest to log a customisation request based on what's written at the bottom here: https://help.sap.com/docs/buying-invoicing/approval-process-management-guide/default-approval-process-for-invoice-reconciliation-documents-for-credit-memos-6b941434c1da101496f78f16a2c6b546

But this talks about adding an approval group to rejected IR documents without exceptions. In our cases, we have exceptions and that makes no difference.

I'm confused as to what sort of customisation will trigger the resubmit of the approval flow after the Reject button is pushed. If anyone here has enabled such a customisation, could you please describe it?

thanks

Cathy

entry.title: Re: LSMW issue in IE02 transaction
entry.content:
If you use LSMW, instead of creating a batch input recording for IE02, you should select the Standard Batch/Direct Input method and use the object for IBIP (program RIBIP00 ‚Äì Initial Load of Equipment Master Data).

That way, the LSMW will trigger IBIP in the background. It is far more stable than a recording of IE02, and in most cases the updates will go through correctly.

entry.title: Re: Error message "Service broker privatelink failed with...
entry.content: Private Link is a hyperscaler-dependent service, thus establishing a private link between two different hyperscalers is not possible. In your case, if you try to establish a private link to your CosmosDB account then you have to make sure that the SAP private link service instance is created from a BTP subaccount with Microsoft Azure as provider.

entry.title: Maintain File In WEB Repository
entry.content:
Transaction code SMW0 in SAP ABAP is the SAP Web Repository. Its primary purpose is to manage binary and text-based objects that are used by various applications within the SAP system, particularly those related to web-based technologies and user interfaces. 

Explanation 

The main types of objects you can manage with SMW0 are: 

  • Binary Data for WebRFC Applications: This is the most common use case. It's for uploading and storing binary files like images, logos, sound files, or other media. These objects can then be referenced and displayed in ABAP programs, SAP GUI screens, or used in forms like Smart Forms. 
  • HTML Templates for WebRFC Applications: This allows developers to store HTML files or templates. These templates can be used to generate dynamic web pages or for sending rich HTML emails from ABAP programs. 
  • XSLT Programs for Transformation: You can also store XSLT (eXtensible Stylesheet Language Transformations) files here, which are used to transform XML documents. 

Common Use Cases for SMW0 

  1. Uploading Company Logos: This is a very frequent use of SMW0. Developers upload a company logo (e.g., in .BMP or .GIF format) as binary data to the repository. The logo is then configured to appear on the SAP Easy Access screen or on reports and forms. 
  2. Displaying Images in ABAP Programs: You can use SMW0 to store images and then display them in your custom ABAP programs by referencing the stored object. This is typically done with ABAP GUI controls, such as CL_GUI_PICTURE. 
  3. Creating Predefined Format Of Files: For eg. In the Excel file need to make few fields as char type in that case  we will use the web repository.

Key Points for ABAP Developers 

  • Object Naming: Objects in SMW0 have a unique name. It's a best practice to use a customer namespace (starting with 'Z' or 'Y') to avoid conflicts with standard SAP objects. 
  • MIME Types: Before uploading a file, you must ensure that its MIME type (e.g., image/jpeg for a JPEG image) is maintained in the system settings within SMW0. 
  • Transportability: Objects created in SMW0 are transportable. You can assign them to a transport request to move them between development, quality assurance, and production systems. 

Steps To add the File in Web repository.

Start the Transaction: Go to transaction code SMW0. 

Select Binary Data: On the initial screen, select the radio button for "Binary data for WebRFC applications" and click the Execute button. 

Define Mime types.

In the Settings->Define Mime Types 

 

 

Click on create button.

Create a New Object: Click on the Create button (or press F5). 

Define Object Details: A dialog box will appear where you'll need to enter the following information: 

OBJID: This is the unique identifier for your file, such as ZSO_UPLOAD_TEMPLATE. 

Description: A short, descriptive text for the object .

Save the Entry: Save the object definition. 

 

 

Import the File: With your newly created object selected, click the Import button. 

Choose the File: A file selection dialog will pop up, allowing you to browse your local computer and choose the file you want to upload. 

Save the Changes: After selecting the file, save your changes. The file content is now stored in the WWWDATA table and is linked to the OBJID you created. 

The entries are added in wwwdata table.

Download the Filed from WWWDATA Table Using report Program.

DATA: lv_objid   TYPE wwwdatatab-objid VALUE 'ZN_UPLOAD_TEMPLATE', 
      ls_objdata TYPE wwwdatatab, 
      lv_file    TYPE string, 
      lv_msg     TYPE string, 
      lv_file1   TYPE rlgrap-filename, 
      lv_subrc   TYPE sy-subrc. 
 
" Get desktop path 
CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>get_desktop_directory 
  CHANGING 
    desktop_directory = lv_file. 
 
CONCATENATE lv_file 'C:\sales\order455.xlsx' INTO lv_file1. 

" Read object metadata 
SELECT SINGLE relid objid INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF ls_objdata 
  FROM wwwdata 
  WHERE srtf2 = 0 AND relid = 'MI' AND objid = lv_objid. 
 
IF sy-subrc = 0. 
  " Download the file 
  CALL FUNCTION 'DOWNLOAD_WEB_OBJECT' 
    EXPORTING 
      key         = ls_objdata 
      destination = lv_file1 
    IMPORTING 
      rc          = lv_subrc. 

   IF lv_subrc = 0. 
     lv_msg =  'Template downloaded sucessfully'. 
     CONCATENATE lv_msg lv_file1 INTO lv_msg. 
     MESSAGE lv_msg TYPE 'S'. 
  ELSE. 
    MESSAGE 'Download failed.' TYPE 'E'. 
  ENDIF. 
ELSE. 
  MESSAGE 'Template not found in repository.' TYPE 'E'. 
ENDIF.

Conclusion.

SMW0 is a specialized SAP transaction code for managing non-transactional files like images and HTML templates. Its primary use case is to store and make these files available for display and use across various SAP applications, particularly for branding and UI purposes.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  •

entry.title: ALMathon 2025: Business Configuration Management
entry.content:
Our team‚Äôs contribution to the ALMathon 2025: Business Configuration Management

We‚Äôre excited to share insights into a solution prototype we developed during the SAP ALMathon 2025: Business Configuration Management (BCM), an extension to SAP Cloud ALM that addresses a white spot in Cloud ALM in the management of business configuration, i.e. customising, across hybrid enterprise landscapes.

Developed during the SAP ALMathon

As part of the ALMathon initiative, our participating team from PwC Deutschland contributed a fully working prototype of BCM. The solution was ideated, designed, and implemented during the hackathon, showcasing how SAP Cloud ALM can be extended to meet real-world customer needs. We‚Äôre proud to have been part of this collaborative innovation effort and are happy to share our learnings and technical insights with the SAP Community.

Managed with SAP Cloud ALM

Throughout the development process, we used SAP Cloud ALM itself to manage the project. From tracking tasks and milestones to coordinating team activities, Cloud ALM provided the transparency and structure needed to deliver BCM efficiently and collaboratively.

Why business configuration management?

SAP Cloud ALM offers robust cloud-native application lifecycle management, but many customers have asked for a centralised customising distribution service. BCM fills this gap by introducing the Business Configuration Hub (BCH) ‚Äì a cloud-native service on SAP BTP that ensures consistent and reliable synchronisation of business configurations across hybrid landscapes.

Challenges addressed

BCM tackles several common pain points:

  • Inconsistent customising across systems
  • Manual synchronisation efforts of customising changes
  • Hybrid landscape complexity that requires structural mappings of key mappings
  • Lack of monitoring and analysis tools to ensure systems stay in synch
  • Missing governance and approval workflows

Key features

  • Centralised UI: Familiar SAP-style interface for synchronizing customising in a golden client
  • Replication: Harmonises data across systems with structural and key mapping
  • Integration: Connects to SAP‚Äôs transport layer for seamless movement of customising settings
  • Workflows & Governance: Role-based approvals and audit trails
  • Harmonization: Monitors distribution consistency and recommends standardisation
  • Cloud-Native Deployment: Hosted on SAP BTP for scalability and reduced infrastructure dependency

 

Architecture highlights

The architecture of BCM is built on SAP BTP and leverages several key components:

    • SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP): Powers the backend services for customising data validation, approval, and distribution.
    • SAP Fiori (UI5): Provides the user interface for customising maintenance and governance workflows.
    • SAP Cloud Connector: Enables secure connectivity between on-premise systems and the cloud-based BCH.
    • SAP HANA Cloud: Stores internal customising data and supports analytics and harmonisation insights.
    • SAP Cloud ALM: Acts as both the project management tool and integration point for transport orchestration.

 

We look forward to engaging with the SAP Community and welcome feedback, questions, and collaboration opportunities. If you're interested in learning more or exploring how BCM could support your organisation, feel free to reach out!

entry.title: SAP on IBM i: SAP Support Required PTF Lists have been updated
entry.content:
Over the last couple of weeks, IBM has investigated some rare cases in the handling of SQL packages that could occasionally result in SQL -901 error codes. The problems have been resolved with PTFs, and the SAP Support Required PTF Lists, formerly known as Information APARs, have been updated to include these new PTFs. Together with these additions, the High Impact/Pervasive PTF groups were updated.

The PTF lists can be found at the following links:

IBM i 7.6: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-76
IBM i 7.5: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-75
IBM i 7.4: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-74

If you want to download the PTF lists to your SAP systems with the help of a program, take a look at our sample program and blog entry from July 18th, 2022.

We recommend that you apply the current PTF levels for preventive maintenance whenever you are performing your next scheduled maintenance.

entry.title: How Modernization with SAP Integration Suite Looks After Go-live
entry.content:
How Modernization with SAP Integration Suite Looks After Go-live

When businesses talk about modernization, the conversation often ends at ‚Äúfaster integrations, lower costs, and improved agility.‚Äù But the real story begins after go-live. That‚Äôs when companies discover how much integration truly influences their day-to-day confidence, decision-making, and ability to grow.

SAP Integration Suite isn‚Äôt just a connector between systems. It‚Äôs a foundation that determines how reliably data flows, how resilient operations become, and how quickly businesses can act. Over the years, I‚Äôve seen clients across various industries realize unexpected benefits, some of which only become apparent once the project is complete.

Beyond Speed and Cost: The Lasting Impact

Yes, speed, agility, and efficiency matter. However, the most significant changes often occur on the business side: enhanced resilience during disruptions, smoother compliance, faster demand response, and stronger partner ecosystems. These outcomes go far beyond what you see in the initial project plan.

Let‚Äôs look at how these benefits show up in practice.

Case Story 1: Real-Time Sales for FMCG

I once worked with a global FMCG company where the team told me: ‚ÄúBy the time we see yesterday‚Äôs sales numbers, the shelves are already empty today.‚Äù

The problem wasn‚Äôt lack of data, they had plenty, but it was buried under custom code and overnight batch jobs. Promotions went live, yet replenishment only followed the next morning. This cost both sales and credibility.

With SAP Integration Suite, the story changed. Event Mesh enabled real-time updates across SAP and non-SAP applications. APIs replaced brittle custom objects. Sales data became same-day data. Planners acted instantly, stockouts dropped, and system performance improved by nearly 50%. Retailers noticed the difference too.

Case Story 2: Compliance and Cost Reduction in Pharma

Pharmaceutical companies face a unique challenge: balancing strict compliance with the pressure to modernize their operations. I remember working closely with a global pharma client that was still running on SAP PO and several legacy middleware tools. Every conversation revealed frustration; IT teams were stretched thin, compliance reports were painstakingly assembled from multiple sources, and maintenance costs continued to climb.

When we introduced SAP Integration Suite, the change was tangible almost immediately. We rebuilt interfaces into modular iFlows with centralized error handling, while APIs became the go-to standard for both internal and partner communications. During one workshop, the compliance team‚Äôs eyes lit up as real-time dashboards provided them with the visibility they had been seeking for years. By the end of the project, the company had cut maintenance costs by 40%, strengthened regulatory compliance, and enabled real-time data exchange across functions ‚Äî all on a modern, event-driven integration backbone built to scale with their business.

Case Story 3: Strengthening the Ecosystem in Manufacturing

I recall visiting the IT operations center of a global power transmission manufacturer, operating in 30+ countries. They were still relying on SAP Neo, which had served them well initially but had become rigid and unable to support multi-cloud strategies. The team was candid: every new initiative felt like a gamble, and IT was constantly firefighting integration issues.

Migrating to SAP Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry changed the dynamics. Key manufacturing and logistics applications were re-platformed, and APIs and integrations were rebuilt for multi-cloud compatibility. Real-time monitoring gave IT a level of visibility and control they had never experienced. I remember the moment the IT director said, ‚ÄúWe finally feel like we can see everything, and trust it.‚Äù

With that being said, the result was remarkable: 50% faster data exchange, full transparency, and a seamless partner experience. Integration was no longer just ‚Äúplumbing‚Äù; it became a strategic lever that strengthened ecosystem collaboration and supported global business growth.

 

The Hidden Wins of Modernization

Some benefits don‚Äôt make it into the launch-day slide deck but show their value every day:

  • Resilience: Processes continue even when one system falters, thanks to monitoring, retries, and built-in error handling.

  • Confidence: CIOs and IT leaders gain visibility into integrations, reducing the stress of hidden risks.

  • Governance: Centralized logs and traces simplify audits, cutting weeks of prep time.

  • Agility: Businesses adapt quickly to market changes because data flows freely across systems and regions.

These shifts are as valuable as the traditional metrics like cost savings or speed. They change how businesses operate ‚Äî and how confidently teams make decisions.

In Short

Modernization with SAP Integration Suite is not just about connecting systems. It‚Äôs about giving businesses the resilience to run without constant firefighting, the confidence to innovate without fear, and the agility to grow without hesitation.

Every company faces unique challenges, but the pattern remains the same: once integrations are modernized, businesses move faster, partners collaborate more easily, and IT can finally focus on value instead of survival. That‚Äôs the true impact of SAP Integration Suite, the benefits that appear after go-live, and the foundation it builds for the future.

entry.title: Deprecation of Intelligent Situation Automation Service
entry.content:
Abstract

Intelligent Situation Automation is an extension of Situation Handling. It processes situations and resolves them automatically using established business rules, thereby reducing the time users spend on routine, manual, and repetitive tasks. Please refer to SAP Discovery Center for more information. 

As part of this blog, we are announcing the deprecation of Intelligent Situation Automation service. 

 

 

What is the current end-of-service date of Intelligent Situation Automation? 

The Intelligent Situation Automation will be under maintenance only mode and the end-of-service date is 6 months from the announcement or when the last contract commitment is fulfilled. 

 

What do you need to do? 

Unsubscribe the Intelligent Situation Automation SaaS solution. Please refer to below steps:

Prerequisite: You are an administrator of the subaccount.

  1. Open your global account in the SAP BTP cockpit and open your subaccount.
  2. In the navigation area of each subaccount, choose Services > Instances and Subscriptions.
  3. Select the three dots at the end of the Intelligent Situation Automation subscription row, and from the menu, select Delete. All data related to the application will be deleted in the respective subaccount.

 If you have any further concern here, please reach out to us.

 

 What‚Äôs next? 

We're thrilled to introduce the new AI-assisted capability of our Situation Handling - Extended Framework and hope you'll join us as we move forward. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, AI-assisted situation handling provides business users with targeted advice. Situation data and its related data context are captured for each business issue and can be used to design prompts. If business users choose AI-generated proposals, they will receive context-specific, actionable solution recommendations tailored to their responsibilities. This feature is not yet generally available; will keep you posted once its available for consumption. 

If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to contact us via component CA-SIT-ATM.

entry.title: SAML SSO configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
How to Configure SAML on SAP Analytics Cloud Tenant Using IAS as a Custom IDP

With SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO), you can simplify authentication for your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) users while improving security and reducing password fatigue. By integrating SAC with SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) (or any other identity provider) as a custom Identity Provider (IdP), you gain centralized control over user access and streamline the login experience.

In this guide, we‚Äôll walk through the process of setting up SAML-based SSO step-by-step ‚Äî from prerequisites to verification ‚Äî ensuring a smooth configuration process for administrators.

What You‚Äôll Learn

This guide is divided into three main sections:

  1. Prerequisites ‚Äì Everything you need to prepare before starting the configuration.

  2. Step-by-Step Configuration ‚Äì Detailed steps to set up SAML SSO between SAC and IAS.

  3. Verification and Go-Live ‚Äì How to verify and finalize your configuration.

  4. Troubleshooting ‚Äì Common issues, tips, and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) to help you quickly resolve errors during or after setup.

By the end, you‚Äôll have a fully functional SAML-based authentication setup, ready for production.

 

Configuring SAML SSO with IAS

Follow these steps carefully to configure SAML authentication for your SAC tenant.

Before you begin, make sure the following requirements are met. Prerequisites for SAC configuration:

  1. You must have an IdP that supports SAML 2.0 protocol.
  2. You must be able to configure your IdP.
  3. You must be assigned to the System Owner role in SAP Analytics Cloud. For more information, see Standard Application Roles.
  4. SAP Analytics Cloud can be hosted either on SAP data centers or on non-SAP data centers. Determine which environment SAP Analytics Cloud is hosted in by inspecting your SAP Analytics Cloud URL:
    • A single-digit number, for example us1 or jp1, indicates an SAP data center.
    • A two-digit number, for example eu10 or us30, indicates a non-SAP data center.
  5. If your users are connecting from Apple devices using the SAP Analytics Cloud mobile app, the certificate used by your IdP must be compatible with Apple's App Transport Security (ATS) feature.

Follow help page to enable SAML SSO : Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider (Legacy Custom IdP)

Configuration steps:

1. Login to SAP Analytics Cloud tenant as System Owner with Default IDP.

2. Navigate to ‚ÄúSystem -> Administration‚Äù.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. From ‚ÄúAdministration‚Äù tab switch to ‚ÄúSecurity‚Äù page, click on Edit button on the right corner and switch to SAML Single Sign-on SSO from SAP Cloud Identity (default).

4. Download metadata file mentioned under Step 1 ‚ÄúDownload Service Provider metadata‚Äù in SAC and save it to your local machine.

5. Upload the SAP Analytics Cloud metadata file to your SAML IdP.

To complete this step, you will need to login to Cloud Identity Provisioning Services (IAS) and navigate to the following path ‚ÄúApplications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> SAML 2.0 Configuration‚Äù. Under ‚ÄúDefine from Metadata‚Äù section click on Browse and upload the metadata file which was downloaded from SAC in step 3 above.

6.  Map your SAML IdP user attributes and roles. 

After SAC metadata has been uploaded into IAS, navigate to ‚ÄúApplications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Attributes‚Äù  and configure SAML mapping as it is defined in step 7 in help page  Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider.

Important! - For SAML attributes to be recognized it is also important that the ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù attribute contains the value of ‚Äúsac''

7. In IAS, navigate to Tenant Settings tab under ''Application & Resources.''

Under Single Sign-on section, click on SAML 2.0 Configuration tab, and download metadata file from there.

Switch back to SAC tenant and continue Step 2 ‚ÄúUpload Identity Provider metadata‚Äù, upload the metadata file there.

8. Now we need to define User Attribute in Step 3 ‚ÄúChoose a user attribute to map to your identity provider‚Äù in SAC. It should map to User ID, Email, or a custom attribute. You can view your SAP Analytics Cloud user attributes in Security Users.

The attribute will be used to map users from your Custom IDP (in this case IAS)  to SAP Analytics Cloud. The user attribute you select must match the NameID (Subject Name Identifier) used in your custom SAML assertion.

In IAS tenant navigate to ‚ÄúApplications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Subject Name Identifier‚Äù and select same User Attribute for  ‚ÄúSelect a basic attribute‚Äù, which was defined in SAP Analytics Cloud.

9. In Step 4, enter <Your Unique Identifier>. This value must identify the SAP Analytics Cloud system owner. The Login Credential provided here will be automatically set for your user.

Which means if attribute is set to email in step 3, then System Owner‚Äôs email should be defined in step 4 as per screenshot below.

10. After above steps have been completed, click on ‚ÄúVerify Account‚Äù. You can copy the URL by selecting  (Copy).

Please Note that: You must use a private session (Incognito) to log onto the URL; for example, Guest mode in Chrome. This ensures that when you log on to the dialog and select SAP Analytics Cloud, you are prompted to log in and do not reuse an existing browser session.

11. In the Verify Your Account dialog, select Check Verification. If the verification was successful, a green border should appear around the Login Credential box.

12. After verification was successful, click on save and conversion to SAML SSO should be completed.

By following all these steps, we have successfully configured SAML SSO on SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

 

What is Identity Provider Administration Tool? 

The Identity Provider Administration tool allows system owners to manage the custom identity provider configured with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Through the tool, the system owner can choose to upload new metadata for the current custom identity provider or revert to using the default identity provider.

You can read more about this tool here: Access the Identity Provider Administration Tool

How to access/use Identity Provider Administration Tool?

In the following, we‚Äôll use Identity Provider Administration tool can be used to update metadata from custom IDP and how to revert SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) tenant back to default IDP.

Pre-requisites:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) must already be configured to use a custom identity provider.
  • You must be the system owner.

Procedure

  1. Log in with an S-user that has the same email address as the system owner of your system. If you don't yet have such an S-user, you can click the ‚ÄúRegister‚Äù button and create a S-user. If you create a new S-user, you'll receive an email with an activation link that will let you set your password.

  2. Access the Identity Provider Administration tool using the following URL pattern:

    https://console.<data center>.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    For example, if your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on eu10, then the URL is:

    https://console.eu10.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    If your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on cn1, then the URL is:

    https://console.cn1.sapanalyticscloud.cn/idp-admin/

    If your tenant is on EUDP:

    https://console-eudp.eu1.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    https://console-eudp.eu2.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

  3. Once you're logged in, you'll see a list of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)systems for which you are the system owner.

  4. Select the system you want to work on by clicking on its row.

Once you're in the settings page for your system, you can see information about your current custom identity provider. If you need to reacquire your system's metadata, you can click the ‚ÄúService Provider Metadata Download‚Äù. 

  1. If you don't want to manage your custom identity provider through Identity Provider Administration, you can disconnect your system by clicking ‚ÄúDisconnect IdP Admin from your system‚Äù.

  2. To proceed with either reverting to the default identity provider or updating the current custom identity provider, select the corresponding radio button and then click ‚ÄúStep 2‚Äù.
  3. (Optional) Revert to the default identity provider.

  4. Choose this option if you're having problems logging in with your custom identity provider and would like to revert to the default identity provider. Once the reversion has finished, you can exit the Identity Provider Administration tool and log in to your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to reconfigure your custom identity provider.

  5. Select the ‚ÄúRevert to default IdP‚Äù radio button to revert to the default IdP. 
    • Select ‚ÄúYes‚Äù in the confirmation dialog to revert your authentication method back to the default IdP.   
    • Click ‚ÄúStep 3‚Äù to proceed to the validation step.   

      ‚ÄÉ
  6. To re-upload the metadata file, use ‚ÄúUpdate IdP Metadata‚Äù button.
  7. On step 2, when prompted, browse for new metadata file and re-upload it.

Relevant KBA:

  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant 
  • 2975954 - Implement multiple Identity Providers (IdP) in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Troubleshooting

If there is any issue/error that comes up when trying to login or when configuring SAML/SSO within SAC, please make sure following is configured correctly.

  • Correct Metadata is uploaded within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) from custom IDP
  • Certificate is not expired within Metadata.
  • Correct ‚ÄúNameID‚Äù is passed from Custom IDP to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If email is used as NameID, make sure the case matches between custom IDP and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If User ID is used as NameID, make sure it‚Äôs all in Capitals
  • During configuring SAML within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) make sure to run verifying URL within INCOGNITO Browser window.

Example: After configuring SAML within SAC Users are not able to login and are getting errors: 

To debug the above error message, please do the steps below:

  1. Collect SAML traces as per KB 2461862 - Collecting SAML traces with Chrome, Edge or Firefox
  2. Open SAML Trace file (.json) within SAML Tracer tool, using ‚ÄúImport‚Äù button
  3. Once opened look for calls with SAML Tags
  4. Select ‚ÄúPOST‚Äù call with SAML Tag and make sure all the required attributes are passed and in correct format. Pay attention to ‚ÄúNameID‚Äù and that it‚Äôs in correct format. 
  5. In the above example trace you can see that there is no ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù attribute is passed and therefore User is not able to login.

Another point which can be checked is the following:

1. To ensure the NameID attributes are matching between the 2 applications you may use the following URL:

https://<system-name>.authentication.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/config?action=who&details=true

2. Run the URL in an incognito browser session. It should redirect to the logon page of the Custom IdP (in this case, IAS) linked to the SAC tenant. After successful logon via the IdP credentials, look for UserName and ExternalId fields.

  • ExternalId - The value that the IdP forwards towards SAC as Subject Name Identifier (Name ID)
  • UserName - The value that is actually being compared to the SAC SAML attribute. This is due to one of the HANA services caching the value of ExternalID and storing it as UserName for faster authentication.

3. If UserName is not matching the SAC SAML attribute - authentication should fail.

NameID should be changed to ensure match between the 2 applications. If userName and SAC SAML attribute is matching - authentication should be successful

 

Conclusion

Integrating SAP Analytics Cloud with SAP Identity Authentication Service using SAML SSO brings a host of benefits:

  • Centralized authentication management across systems.

  • Enhanced security through standardized protocols.

  • Improved user experience with seamless, passwordless access.

By following this step-by-step guide, you‚Äôve successfully configured a robust and secure SAML connection between SAC and IAS. Your users can now enjoy a simplified login experience, while you maintain full control over authentication and role management.

Relevant KBAs:

  • 2487567 - Troubleshooting SAML assertions when configuring SAML SSO in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • 2922448 - SAML Attribute Mapping in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) & SAP Digital Boardroom Master KBA
  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant
  • 2879161 - How to update the SAML IdP Signing Certificate or Metadata.xml in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

entry.title: New in CRUN Job Mon: Job End Time, Runtime, and Direct Remote Access from Alert Notification
entry.content:
In enterprise applications, even small usability improvements can lead to significant efficiency gains. When users spend less time navigating through multiple systems to get simple answers, they can focus more on decision-making and less on operations.

That‚Äôs exactly what our two latest enhancements in SAP Job and Automation Monitoring aim to achieve. With these updates, users now get richer job execution data and direct navigation to remote systems all from within the alert notification email.

Background: What Triggers an Alert Notification?

SAP Job and Automation Monitoring allow users to configure alerts based on specific job execution events, such as:

  • Critical Application Status
  • Critical Execution Status
  • Critical Runtime
  • Critical Delay

When one of these conditions defined for above event is met, the system sends an email alert (if configured), containing a summary of the issue.

Until recently, this alert included basic job run data but required users to open the monitoring app or navigate to the remote system to get more detailed information.

Feature 1: View Job End Time and Runtime in the Email Itself

The Problem:

Previously, the alert email did not include the job end time or total runtime. Users had to:

  • Open the Job and Automation Monitoring application, or
  • Manually navigate to the remote system

Just to see how long a job ran or when it finished.

The Solution:

We‚Äôve now added two new fields directly in the Run Info table of the alert email:

  • Job End Time
  • Total Runtime

This eliminates the need for extra steps just to access basic metrics.

Benefit: Users now get a full snapshot of the job execution without ever leaving their inbox ‚Äî reducing context-switching and improving speed of response.

Feature 2: Direct Navigation to Remote System from the Alert

The Problem:

When users needed to investigate a specific job run, they had to:

  1. Open the Job and Automation Monitoring app in CALM
  2. Locate the job
  3. Then navigate to the remote system

This was cumbersome, especially for teams whose only need was to view job-level details in the remote system. It also required unnecessary CALM access for team members.

The Solution:

Now, each job‚Äôs Run ID in the alert email is a clickable hyperlink that:

  • Directly navigates to the corresponding job instance in the remote system
  • Requires only the user‚Äôs remote system credentials
  • Bypasses CALM, reducing overhead and simplifying access

How It Works: Since each system may have a unique URL structure, we implemented logic to dynamically generate the correct remote URL for each job and embed it in the notification.

Benefit: Monitoring teams can now act faster, access job details instantly, and avoid managing unnecessary CALM permissions for team members who only need remote access.

Conclusion: Simplifying Monitoring, One Feature at a Time

These two enhancements mark a key step forward in making SAP Job and Automation Monitoring not only a powerful tool but also an intuitive and efficient one.

With:

  • Richer job data directly in email alerts
  • One-click access to job details in remote systems

we‚Äôre reducing friction, saving time, and empowering teams to resolve issues faster.

Useful Links

  • Expert portal

entry.title: Course Update: Understanding the Purpose of SAP Commerce Cloud, its Components and User Roles
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to announce an important update to the course: 

Understanding the Purpose of SAP Commerce Cloud, its Components and User Roles‚Äã 

Whether you‚Äôre a newcomer or an experienced professional wanting to stay on top of the latest features, this updated learning journey is designed for you! The course aims to introduce you to the foundational skills, including user interfaces and key tasks associated with various SAP Commerce Cloud business user roles.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this training, business users and consultants will be able to describe the purpose and basic elements of SAP Commerce Cloud. They will understand the key tasks associated with different business user roles and learn how these users leverage the platform's powerful interfaces to enhance customer experience and increase sales.

The learning journey consists of 8 units:

  • Describing SAP Commerce Cloud Essentials: Purpose, Structure, and User Roles: This unit summarizes the SAP Commerce Cloud‚Äôs purpose, main components, its place in the CX product family, and the roles and interfaces used by back-end users.
  • Working with Products in the Backoffice Product Cockpit: This unit introduces the SAP Commerce Cloud Product Manager persona and explains their main daily tasks. It also describes the structure, synchronization, and management of product catalogs in the Backoffice Product Cockpit‚Äã. A more detailed course for this persona can be found here: Managing Products in the Backoffice Product Cockpit 
  • Building a Business-to-Consumer (B2C) Webstore:  Gain an understanding of web content management fundamentals and learn how SmartEdit supports the typical tasks of a Web Content Manager. If you need more information about the Web Content Manager role, please refer to the dedicated course below: Creating and Configuring Web Content for SAP Commerce Cloud
  • Working in the Backoffice Administration Perspective as a Business User:  Learn the main features, use cases, and typical tasks of the Backoffice Administration Cockpit.
  • Configuring Search Experience: Learn how business users can improve customer search experience and the typical tasks of a Search Manager. Additional information about SAP Commerce Cloud search capabilities can be found here: Transforming Search Dynamics using Search Service and AI-Driven Intelligent Search in SAP Commerce Cloud  
  • Managing Promotions and Coupons: Learn the key elements of product promotion with discounts and incentives, and discover the typical tasks of a Marketing Manager in managing promotions and coupons. If you need additional information about the Marketing Manager persona and the Promotions and Coupons capabilities on SAP Commerce Cloud, you can the following standalone course: Creating Promotions and Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud 
  • Fulfilling Orders: Learn the key steps of the order fulfillment process and the typical tasks of an Order Fulfillment Manager in Backoffice.
  • Assisting Customers: Learn about the default customer support tools‚Äîsuch as the Assisted Service Module and Customer Support Cockpit‚Äîand the typical activities customer support agents perform while assisting customers on the storefront.
     

The total duration of this learning journey is around 3 hours. The learning journey contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The Learning Journey is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this learning journey and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: A day in the life of a cloud ERP implementation consultant at SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin
entry.content:
As a cloud ERP implementation consultant, I‚Äôm always looking for ways to sharpen my skills, stay on top of innovations, and connect with peers who face the same challenges in customer projects. For me, SAP TechEd has always been the place where all of this comes together and I‚Äôm sure TechEd 2025 in Berlin will be no different.

It‚Äôs not just about listening to sessions. It‚Äôs about walking away with concrete knowledge and hands-on experience I can apply on Monday morning with my customers. Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôve built my personal agenda for TechEd 2025.

Hopefully, it gives you some inspiration for planning your own.

 

Day 1 - Getting started with the big picture

My first day is about getting inspired, hearing the strategy, and understanding the direction of SAP‚Äôs Business Suite and cloud ERP.

  • 9:30 AM - 9:55 AM CET:
    ST108 | Stop managing complexity: Start building what really matters
  • 10:30 AM - 11:15 AM CET:
    DT102 | Choosing the right path to SAP Business Suite for your business
  • 12:30 PM - 12:55 PM CET:  
    PAR101 | Accelerate your IT transformation with process-aware agentic testing
  • 12:30 PM - 2:30 PM CET:
    DT161 | Implementation experience for SAP Cloud ERP

Day 2 - Deep Dive into daily bread and butter

Day 2 is where I get into the practical details that matter most for my projects.

  • 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM CET:
    DT262 | Implementation accelerators for SAP Cloud ERP
    I need to speed up here to make it to my next favorited session. üòâ
  • 12:15 PM - 1:00 PM CET:
    DT100 | From onboarding to go-live with SAP Cloud ERP
  • 1:00 PM - 3:00 PM CET:
    DT264 | How to start transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private
  • 4:15 PM - 5:00 PM CET:
    DT103 | Guidance to ease your transition to SAP Cloud ERP Private

Day 3 - Looking ahead and staying competitive

The final day is all about exploring future trends and preparing for what‚Äôs next.

  • 9:00 AM - 9:45 AM CET:
    BTM105 | Shaping the future with integrated IT and business process management
  • 10:30 AM - 10:55 AM CET:
    DT105 | SAP Business AI in SAP Cloud ERP with SAP and Accenture
  • 12:00 PM - 12:45 PM CET:
    AI105 | Building custom AI agents and skills with Joule Studio
  • In the afternoon, I also plan to spend time at the demo pod.
    A great chance to discuss my long list of topics with experts and get practical advice for customer projects:
    DT917 | Cloud ERP implementation and transition paths

Final thoughts

As an implementation consultant, I know the daily reality: deadlines, requirements, and the pressure to deliver. SAP TechEd 2025 helps me reset, recharge, and return with new knowledge that directly impacts my work.

If you‚Äôre an implementation consultant like me, TechEd isn‚Äôt just another event. It‚Äôs where our role gets the spotlight and where we walk away better equipped to help customers succeed.

Save the date and register today 
November 4-6, 2025 
SAP TechEd Berlin | SAP TechEd Virtual

Hello @FaisalMaayeh 

Warehouse management is activated on storage location level by assigning a warehouse number to a storage location. Several storage locations can be assigned to a single warehouse number but not vice versa.

You can't activate it WM/EWM on plant level.

entry.title: Re: Query error when adding a variable [%0]
entry.content:
Write the following comment at the beginning of your query:

/*
SELECT
FROM "JDT1" T0
WHERE T0."RefDate" <= '[%0]'
*/

This comment will help SAP understand which SAP field the parameter [%0] belongs to, what the parameter means, and what heading the parameter should have.

Then you can use the parameter '[%0]' in the query:

entry.title: Re: What is the organizational level of Warehouse Managem...
entry.content:
Dear @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question.

Question 1: 101A and 105W are both IM storage locations. They sit at the same organizational level Client ‚Üí Company Code ‚Üí Plant ‚Üí Storage Location. 105W is simply a WM-managed storage location (flagged as WM-relevant) and 101A is a non-WM storage location. Same level; different behavior. Inside the warehouse number you have the WM topology (storage types ‚Üí sections ‚Üí bins). IM doesn‚Äôt know about bins‚ÄîIM only posts to storage locations.

Question 2: No, You must have at least one storage location flagged as WM-relevant and assigned to the warehouse number.

Below more details about IM and WM in Public Cloud: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/4e3737b30b174a5bbd327cfb38f50745.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/87f9b54f9c4f4e75aff0061860a6589a/4ecb88b8b2422afee10000000a42189e.html

Best Regards,

Dawid
